"Like floating in space, away from any gravitational pulls." Actually, no matter where the astronaut is in the universe, gravity would pull on them from at least one massive object. The gravity of the sun still pulls on us, but the earth's gravity is relatively stronger, thus we're not flying toward the sun. Even if we were between galaxies, the combined mass of the clusters of galaxies around would have an effect. http://www.yalescientific.org/2010/10/mythbusters-does-zero-gravity-exist-in-space/

Actually, it would be more correct to speak of a trajectory ellipse rather than a parabola. A parabola only appears in the theoretical case of a gravitational field with parallel acceleration vectors. On our round earth, all acceleration vectors point towards earth's center, making any thrown object (ball, satellite, moon, etc.) move on an elliptic path around it.

When you "float" out in space you are actually falling.  If you were not rotating around the earth but rather being held in place out in space, you would still experience the gravity of the earth.

Small nitpick: General Relativity does indeed say that acceleration and gravity are indistinguishable, but only for a uniform gravitational field (or at a single point). Because gravitational fields are usually generated by a sphere, the intensity and direction of gravity actually varies slightly from point to point, meaning that the force acting on a body varies depending on which bit of the body you're talking about. From the perspective of an object in free fall, this feels like a vertical stretching force combined with a horizontal squeezing force - these "tidal forces" are what cause tides, and are what can allow you to tell that there's a significant mass nearby.

If being an object in free-fall truly cancelled out gravity and acceleration perfectly, we wouldn't have tides.

Objects in freefall near earth don't follow a parabola. They follow an ellipse. It's a conic section like any other orbit. It's the same as other orbits, just part of an orbit.  An orbit that intersects the surface of the Earth. One of the foci of that orbit is the mass centre of the Earth-ball system. If objects actually followed a parabola then there'd be no escape velocity. There's no term in the parabolic equation that brings in the inverse square law of gravity. The acceleration due to gravity is constant at 9.8 m/s^2. If you shot something straight up at a third of the speed of light, it would come to rest with respect to the Earth after slightly over 100 million seconds, (or a bit over 3 years) and begin to fall back. What you're describing is the physics of an infinite disk world.

Also not being able to tell the difference between being in a gravitating field and open space depends on ignoring tidal effects. Again, that's the physics of an infinite flat disk for a world.

It is interesting that we use the word "weightless" to describe the phenomenon where all forces, except gravity, have been removed. Gravity is unique in that it doesn't deform us and deformation is what we feel (e.g. chair on butt as mentioned in the video). There is no device that can be built that can detect gravity.
